questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with red, subcutaneous violaceous swelling over the cervical region from the last several months. Some of the lesions ulcerated & underwent spontaneous healing leaving typical cord like scars. Infection of the underlying cervical lymph node is present with multiple sinuses. Histology showed marked caseous necrosis. Labs revealed CD4 count< 50 cells/mm3. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Scrofuloderma

 

Option A: The given image shows subcutaneous swelling over cervical lymph node region which are forming sinuses & healing with cord like scars, all these are classical features of Scrofuloderma. It is a multibacillary manifestation of cutaneous tuberculosis.

 

  • It is the most common form of cutaneous tuberculosis in children. However, it can still be seen in adults, so the age group mentioned in the MCQ as adults does not change the answer here. (Lupus vulgaris is the most common type in adults.)

  • It results from contiguous spread to the skin from an underlying tuberculous focus.

  • This focus could usually be a lymph gland, an infected bone or joint, or a lacrimal gland or duct.

 

Scrofuloderma: Progression of the lesions is as follows:

 

  • Begins as subcutaneous swellings that are bluish-red and asymptomatic, and this stage lasts for months.

  • These subcutaneous swellings, degenerates into undermined ulcers.

  • In ulcers, granulation tissue proliferation results in fungating masses.

  • Several fistulae may develop and cause sinuses to drain onto the skin.

 

Histology reveals pronounced caseating necrosis, which typically contains lots of bacteria.

Although spontaneous healing is possible, the process takes a very long time and results in the typical, cord-like scars.

 

Antituberculosis therapy should be commenced promptly.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lupus vulgaris:

 

  • Lupus vulgaris is a chronic form of cutaneous tuberculosis with apple jelly nodules, typically not associated with deep nodules, ulceration, or sinus tracts as in this case.

 

Option C. Acne vulgaris:

 

  • Acne vulgaris is a common skin condition characterized by comedones, papules, and pustules, not by ulceration or sinus tract formation, and is not associated with caseous necrosis or immunocompromised states.

 

Option D. Erythema nodosum:

 

  • Erythema nodosum presents as tender red nodules, typically on the lower legs, and does not lead to ulceration or sinus tract formation. It is also not associated with caseous necrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of red, subcutaneous violaceous swelling that ulcerates and heals with scarring, coupled with infected cervical lymph nodes and sinus tract formation, in an immunocompromised patient with a low CD4 count and histology showing caseous necrosis, is indicative of scrofuloderma, a cutaneous form of tuberculosis.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 27 Page No 27.13

choices.text: Anatomist's Wart is the other name
Post Primary Tuberculosis with poor immunity
It is a paucibacillary lesion
Antitubercular Therapy is used in the management

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about tuberculosis verrucosa cutis EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Post Primary Tuberculosis with poor immunity

 

Explanation:

 

Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis—

 

  • Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis (TBVC, also known as prosecutor’s Wart, Anatomist's Wart (OptionA), Verruca Necrogenica, and Warty Tuberculosis) is a form of Cutaneous TB that occurs after direct inoculation of the mycobacteria into the skin of a previously sensitized host with good immunity against the bacillus. (OptionB)
  • Inoculation typically occurs from an exogenous source.
  • In adults, TBVC most frequently develops on the Acral Extremities; the Fingers and Dorsum of the hands are commonly affected. The Ankles or Buttocks are frequent sites for lesion occurrence in children.

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • The skin lesions are usually solitary and manifest as painless, violaceous, or brown, red, indurated warty plaques that range from 1 to 5 cm in diameter. TBVC grows via peripheral extension.

 

Histopathology:

 

  • Due to the strong immune response, the lesion is paucibacillary (OptionC).
  • Histology shows hyperkeratosis with no granulomas.

 

Treatment:

 

  • The treatment of cutaneous TB is the same as that for systemic TB.
  • Antitubercular therapy is used in the management (OptionD)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tuberculosis Verrucosa Cutis, also known as Anatomist's Wart is a paucibacillary cutaneous tuberculosis that occurs in individuals with a good or moderate level of immunity and is managed with Antitubercular Therapy.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 27 Page No 27.19

questions.text: Identify Tuberculids among the following options?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lichen Scrofulosorum

 

Option B:

 

Tuberculids

 

Hypersensitivity reaction to M. Tuberculosis or its products in a patient with significant immunity.

 

  • The main features of Tuberculids are:
    • Positive tuberculin test.
    • Evidence of manifest or past tuberculosis.
    • Paucibacillary status.
    • Positive response to antituberculous therapy.
  • True Tuberculids can be grouped as follows:
    • Micropapular: Lichen scrofulosorum.
    • Papular: PapulonecroticTuberculid.
    • Nodular: Erythema induratum of Bazin; nodular Tuberculid.

 

Lichen scrofulosorum:

 

  • Lichenoid eruption of minute papules.
  • Asymptomatic tiny closely grouped perifollicular lichenoid papules which may be skin coloured or yellowish or reddish-brown.
  • The common sites of occurrence are the trunk and the proximal limbs.

 

Image depicts Lichen scrofulosorum with papules over trunk:

 

 

  • Occurs predominantly in children and adolescents with tuberculosis.
  • Associated with a strongly positive tuberculin reaction. It is because of an immune response to haematological spread from an underlying tuberculous focus.

 

Papulonecrotic Tuberculid:

 

  • It is an eruption of necrotizing papules.
  • Lesions are hard, dusky papules that crust or ulcerate to heal with atrophic scars.
  • Affects extensor aspect of the extremities occurring in symmetric crops.
  • Predominantly affecting young adults.

 

Treatment: Treatment of the Tuberculids is by treating the underlying tuberculosis with appropriate antitubercular therapy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lupus Vulgaris:

 

  • This is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis characterized by reddish-brown papules or nodules with apple jelly nodules.
  • It is not a tuberculid but rather a specific form of cutaneous tuberculosis.

 

Option C. Scrofuloderma:

 

  • Scrofuloderma is not a tuberculid but a form of cutaneous tuberculosis characterized by skin ulcers and abscesses.
  • It is not related to hypersensitivity reactions.

 

Option D. Warty Tuberculosis:

 

  • Tuberculosis Verrucosa Cutis—Tuberculosis Verrucosa Cutis (TBVC, also known as prosecutor’s wart, Anatomist's wart, verruca necrogenica, and warty tuberculosis) is a form of cutaneous TB that occurs after direct inoculation of the mycobacteria into the skin of a previously sensitized host with good immunity against the bacillus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tuberculids, such as lichen scrofulosorum, represent cutaneous hypersensitivity reactions to mycobacterial antigens in individuals with a high degree of immunity to tuberculosis and no active mycobacterial infection at the site of skin lesions.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 27 Page No 27.25 27.28

choices.text: M. M. Kansasii

questions.text: Buruli Ulcer is caused by?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) M. Ulcerans

 

Option B:

 

  • Buruli ulcer is caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans.
  • Buruli ulcer is the third most common mycobacterial skin infection in immunocompetent people.

 

 

Epidemiology: It is endemic to Africa and Australia, where it affects children and elderly people. After inoculation into the skin, M. ulcerans proliferates and produces toxin Mycolactone. The physiopathology of Buruli ulcer is closely associated with diffusion of the toxin from bacterial foci.

 

Clinical Features: Initial lesion starts as a nodule or papule which progresses further to form an extensive, necrotic ulcer, which is painless, exposing muscle and tendon. Most lesions occur on the lower extremities.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. M. Avium-Intracellulare:

 

  • This bacterium is associated with infections in immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with HIV/AIDS.
  • It is not the cause of Buruli ulcer.

 

Option C. M. Kansasii:

 

  • M. kansasii, which is another mycobacterial species but not the cause of Buruli ulcer.

 

Option D. M. Tuberculosis:

 

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis is the causative agent of tuberculosis (TB) but is not responsible for Buruli ulcer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Buruli ulcer, a chronic skin infection resulting in large ulcers primarily on the limbs, is caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 27 Page No 27.38

choices.text: Fish Tank Granuloma is caused by Mycobacterium Ulcerans
Eating infected Tuna Fishes causes Fish Tank Granuloma
Erythema Induratum of Bazin is due to Hypersensitivity reaction to M. Tuberculosis
Erythema Nodosum is an example for Lobular Panniculitis

questions.text: Identify the true statement among the following options?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Erythema induratum of Bazin is due to Hypersensitivity reaction to M. tuberculosis.

 

Option C:

 

Erythema induratum of Bazin:

 

  • Recurrent nodular and ulcerative lesions.
  • Occurs secondary to tuberculosis elsewhere in the body,i.e,due to Hypersensitivity reaction to M. tuberculosis
  • Lesions are commonly seen in lower legs (calf), but can affect other areas.
  • The ulcers ragged, irregular and shallow with a bluish edge.

 

 

Option A: Fish tank granuloma or swimming pool granuloma is caused by Mycobacterium marinum (NOT Ulcerans).

 

Option B: M. Marinum enters the body through abrasions or minor cuts on the skin (NOT due to eating fish), which come into contact with contaminated fresh or saltwater.

 

Option D: Erythema Nodosum:

 

  • Erythema nodosum is an example for septal panniculitis (NOT Lobular), it is characterized by Painful, Erythematous, and sometimes Ecchymotic Nodules on the anterior surface of the legs.
  • This commonly occurs in young women.
  • The condition may be idiopathic or could occur secondary to streptococcal infections, and sarcoidosis, Hodgkin’s and non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, leukaemia, and renal cell carcinoma. Rarely tuberculosis could also be a cause of erythema nodosum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Erythema induratum of Bazin is a hypersensitivity reaction to Mycobacterium tuberculosis and is classified as a tuberculid.
  • It typically presents with tender nodules on the back of the legs.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 27 Page No 27.29 27.31

choices.text: Presents with tiny pinhead sized papules mainly on forearms
Most commonly seen in elderly individuals

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy has tiny pinhead sized flesh-colored papules over his elbow & penis. Histopathology of the lesion reveals the following feature. Which of the following is NOT TRUE about this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Most commonly seen in elderly individuals

 

Option B:

 

  • As seen in the picture, Lichen Nitidus has a distinctive histopathology that resembles a claw clutching a ball.
  • Lichen nitidus most frequently affects Children or Young Adults. (NOT ELDERLY)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The dorsum of the forearms or penis is where Lichen Nitidus most commonly manifests as tiny pinhead-sized flesh-coloured papules.

 

  • In early lesions, Lichen Nitidus and Lichen planus share a similar histological profile.

 

Option D: Mucous membrane involvement is quite rare.

 

Option C: True Koebners phenomenon is evident.

 

  • Lesions are self-limiting& no treatment is required.

 

 

Ball and Claw Arrangement:

 

  • The Ball is comprised of well circumscribed granulomatous infiltrate of lymphocytes, epithelioid cells & occasional Langhan’s giant cells that are clutched by surrounding hyperplastic rete ridges, giving the overall claw clutching ball appearance.
  • Lesions are typically asymptomatic and infrequently need medical attention.

 

The histology of Lichen Nitidus is shown in the image below, where a well-defined granuloma is surrounded by rete pegs and appears to be claw clutching a ball.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lichen nitidus, characterized by tiny pinhead-sized flesh-colored papules, commonly affects children and young adults, can exhibit Koebner's phenomenon, and rarely involves mucous membranes. It is not most commonly seen in elderly individuals.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 37 Page No 37.10 37.11

Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology 9thEdition Page No 554

questions.text: A 24-years man presents with a tender erythematous plaque in the groin. It has been there for 4 years and slowly progressing. Examination revealed well demarcated indurated annular shaped plaque with irregular borders which was progressing towards one side & scarring on another border. There was no regional lymphadenopathy, and systemic examination revealed no abnormalities. Considering the above features, a diagnosis of most common type of Cutaneous tuberculosis in adults is made. Which of the following statements is FALSE about this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is a Multibacillary Lesion

 

Explanation:

 

Diagnosis is Lupus Vulgaris & it is a Paucibacillary condition.

 

Points in favour are

 

  1. Age (24 years) - LV is more common in children and young adults
  2. History of exposure to tuberculosis
  3. Chronic presentation (4 years)
  4. Progressive nature
  5. Annular erythematous plaque with irregular borders.
  6. Induration
  7. Healing with scarring

​​​​​​​

  • All of the above findings are in favour of lupus vulgaris.

 

Lupus Vulgaris

 

  • Lupus vulgaris is a chronic form of skin TB seen in patients with moderate immunity to TB bacilli
  • It is seen more common in females.

 

Pathogenesis:

 

  • It occurs due to hematogenous, lymphatic, or contiguous spread from elsewhere in the body, or from exogenous inoculation. It occurs in previously sensitized hosts with good immunity, hence Paucibacillary. (OptionB)

 

Clinical features

 

  • It presents as single or few Erythematous / Violaceous Annular Plaques with Central Scarring and extending Centrifugally.(OptionC)
  • The periphery shows erythematous deep-seated nodules which on diascopy may stand out as Apple jelly nodules. (OptionD)
  • They are most commonly seen in buttocks, upper extremities, and face.
  • The center is depigmented with paper-thin scar.
  • Papules may recur in the scarred areas, which enlarge and coalesce. This leads to the formation of large, firm, elevated plaques.

 

Diagnosis

 

  • Histologic examination & a positive culture for M. tuberculosis/ bovis confirm the diagnosis.
  • Most prominent histopathologic feature: Typical granulomas with scanty or absent caseation.

 

Complication

 

  • Secondary scarring& squamous cell carcinomas may develop rarely.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Anti-Tubercular Drugs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lupus vulgaris is a paucibacillary condition occurring in previously sensitized patients, characterized by slow progression, healing with central scarring, and the potential presence of apple jelly nodules on diascopy.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 27 Page No 27.21 27.22

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4thEdition Page No 1306

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with multiple pinpointed dome shaped skin lesions over hands as shown in the image below. What is TRUE about the diagnosis of the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mucous Membrane is not involved.

 

Option D: The diagnosis for a patient who is presented with multiple pinpointed dome shaped skin lesions over hands is Lichen nitidus.

 

Lichen Nitidus.

 

It typically presentsSmall, Shiny, Skin-Colored Papules on the skin, and while it shares some clinical features with Lichen Planus, Mucous Membranes are typically notinvolved in Lichen Nitidus.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. An id reaction is a secondary skin eruption occurring in response to a primary infection or inflammation elsewhere in the body. Lichen nitidus is not classified as an id reaction.

 

Option B. Koebnerization, or the Koebner phenomenon, can occur in lichen nitidus, where new lesions develop in areas of skin trauma.

 

Option C. Wickham's striae are classically associated with lichen planus, not lichen nitidus, and are not a feature of this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lichen nitidus is characterized by numerous small, shiny papules primarily on the skin, with the mucous membranes generally not involved.
  • It is important to differentiate it from lichen planus, which can involve the mucous membranes and present with Wickham's striae.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 37.10

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4thEdition Page No 203

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with a chronic, progressive skin lesion on her buttock. On physical examination, a well-demarcated, erythematous plaque with deep-seated nodules is noted which was progressing at one end and becoming atrophied at the other end as shown in the image below. Diascopy of the nodules reveals an "apple jelly" color. The patient has a history of a positive tuberculin skin test but no history of active tuberculosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lupus Vulgaris

 

Option A:

 

  • This diagnosis correlates with the clinical features described in the vignette, including the chronicity of the lesion, the presentation of well-demarcated plaques progressing at one end and becoming atrophied at the other end with apple jelly nodules on diascopy, and the patient's history of a positive tuberculin skin test.

 

 

Above image depicts Apple Jelly Nodules

 

  • Lupus vulgaris is a chronic form of cutaneous tuberculosis that occurs in previously sensitized individuals with moderate immunity to Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • It presents with well-demarcated plaques that can have apple jelly nodules on diascopy.
  • This is consistent with the patient's presentation and history of a positive tuberculin skin test, making it the most likely diagnosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Psoriasis

 

  • This typically presents as well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scales, most commonly on extensor surfaces, and scalp.

 

 

  • It is associated with systemic manifestations such as psoriatic arthritis and does not produce apple jelly nodules on diascopy.

 

Option C. Sarcoidosis

 

  • It is a multisystem granulomatous disorder that can present with skin manifestations known as lupus pernio, which can appear similar to lupus vulgaris but is associated with systemic symptoms such as dyspnea, cough, and ocular involvement.

 

 

  • It can present with apple jelly nodules on diascopy, but rest of the features which are in favor of Lupus vulgaris help us to rule out this option.

 

Option D. Granuloma Aannulare

 

  • This is a benign, self-limited dermatological condition that presents with annular plaques which are Non itchy and lack any scaling, presenttypically over joints and is not associated with the apple jelly nodules seen in cutaneous tuberculosis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The clinical features of Lupus Vulgaris, a form of cutaneous tuberculosis, including the well-demarcated plaque, deep-seated nodules, and the characteristic "Apple Jelly" Colour on diascopy.
  • Understand the association with a positive tuberculin skin test and the chronic, progressive nature of the condition.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 27 Page No 27.21 27.22

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4thEdition Page No 1306

choices.text: Apple jelly nodules can be seen on biopsy
It is a type of post-primary inoculation tuberculosis
The patient has low immunity
Treatment is cautery of the lesion

questions.text: A six-year-old child presents with a single warty plaque on the elbow. Upon examination, the lesion is well-demarcated, raised, and verrucous. The patient has no significant past medical history and reports no recent fevers, weight loss, or night sweats. A biopsy of the lesion is performed, revealing non-caseating granulomas. No other skin lesions are noted on physical examination. Given the clinical and histopathological findings, which of the following statements is true about the condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is a type of post-primary inoculation tuberculosis

 

Option B:

 

  • The presentation of a warty plaque and the biopsy finding of non-caseating granulomas suggest tuberculosis verrucosa cutis (TBVC), which is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis that occurs after direct inoculation of the organism into the skin of someone who has good immunity to Mycobacterium tuberculosis, typically because of a previous infection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Apple jelly nodules can be seen on biopsy:

 

  • Apple jelly nodules are observed on clinical examination as translucent yellow-brown nodules after diascopy.
  • They are seen in Lupus vulgaris, Leishmaniasis and Sarcoidosis.

 

Option C. The patient has low immunity:

 

  • The development of non-caseating granulomas in response to Mycobacterium tuberculosis suggests a competentcell-mediated immune response.
  • In immunocompromised patients, tuberculosis lesions may not form granulomas due to an inadequate immune response.

 

Option D. Treatment is cautery of the lesion:

 

  • The mainstay of treatment for tuberculosis verrucosa cutis is anti-tuberculous therapy, not cautery.

 

 

  • Regression of lesion after 3months of ATT.
  • Cautery may be used for certain skin conditions, but not typically for infectious diseases like tuberculosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The correct identification of a warty plaque with non-caseating granulomas on biopsy in a child with no systemic symptoms suggests tuberculosis verrucosa cutis, a form of post-primary inoculation tuberculosis.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 27.19

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4thEdition Page No 1306

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents with chronic facial lesions, characterized by erythematous plaques with central scarring and an advancing edge, as shown in the image. There is no history of systemic symptoms such as fever or weight loss, and the patient reports a gradual progression of the lesions over several months. The patient lives in an urban setting with no known exposure to armadillos or endemic areas for leprosy. A biopsy is performed, which is expected to show granulomatous inflammation. Which of the following treatment will be started in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rifampicin:

 

Option D: Rifampicin:

 

  • Clinical picture shows presence of erythematous plaque with central scarring and an advancing edge, which is suggestive of a clinical diagnosis of Lupus vulgaris.
  • Rifampicin is an antibiotic that is part of the standard Anti-Tuberculous Therapy (ATT). It is used in combination with other medications such as Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide, and Ethambutol for the treatment of cutaneous tuberculosis like lupus vulgaris.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Amphotericin B:

 

  • Amphotericin B is an antifungal medication used for serious systemic fungal infections.
  • It is not indicated in the treatment of cutaneous tuberculosis.

 

Option B. Itraconazole:

 

  • Itraconazole is an antifungal agent that is commonly used for fungal infections of the skin like dermatophytosis.
  • It would not be effective against mycobacterial infections.

 

Option C. Minocycline:

 

  • Minocycline is a tetracycline antibiotic with anti-inflammatory properties, often used for acne vulgaris.
  • It is not the treatment of choice for mycobacterial skin infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The appropriate treatment for lupus vulgaris, a form of cutaneous tuberculosis, is antituberculous therapy which includes rifampicin as part of a combination regimen.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 27.21

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4thEdition Page No 1311

choices.text: Erythema Nodosum occurs over Anterior Leg.
Lichen Scrofulosorum presents as Pruritic Lichenoid Papules over Trunk.
Multiple Bacilli can be seen in Skin Biopsy.
Patient has good response to ATT.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is TRUE regarding Tuberculid?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Patient has good response to ATT.

 

OptionD:

 

  • Patients with tuberculids typically have a good response to antituberculous therapy (ATT) because tuberculids are an immunologic response to mycobacterial antigens, and the immune system is generally competent in these individuals.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Erythema nodosum occurs over anterior leg:

 

  • While erythema nodosum typically presents on the anterior aspect of the legs, it is not classified as a True tuberculid. Erythema nodosum is a form of septalpanniculitis that can be associated with various systemic diseases, including tuberculosis.

 

Option B. Lichen scrofulosorum presents as pruritic lichenoid papules over trunk:

 

  • Lichen scrofulosorum does present as lichenoid papules, but they are typically not pruritic and are considered a tuberculid.

 

Option C. Multiple bacilli can be seen in skin biopsy:

 

  • Tuberculids are paucibacillary, meaning there are few or no detectable bacilli within the lesions. They represent a hypersensitivity reaction to mycobacterial antigens rather than a direct bacterial infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The true statement about tuberculids is that patients have a good response to antituberculous therapy (ATT), as tuberculids are a hypersensitivity reaction to mycobacterial antigens in individuals with generally competent immune systems.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 27.25

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4thEdition Page No 1307

questions.text: A young man presents with the following skin lesions as shown in the image below. Which of the following organisms can least likely spread through dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Staphylococcus Aureus

 

Option B: Given image depicts ulcerating nodules in a linear pattern suggesting Nodular lymphangitis.

 

  • Staphylococcus aureus typically causes localized or systemic infections through direct invasion rather than spreading via dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics.
  • While it can cause lymphatic involvement in the form of lymphangitis, it is more commonly associated with abscesses or cellulitis.
  • So among the given options, Staphylococcus Aureus is the least likely organism to manifest along lymphatics.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mycobacterium Marinum

 

  • It can cause a chronic condition known as "aquarium granuloma" or "fish tank granuloma," which can spread along the lymphatics.

 

Option C. Nocardia

 

  • It can cause cutaneous nocardiosis, which may manifest as lymphocutaneous disease, with spread along lymphatic channels.

 

Option D. Sporothrix schenckii

 

  • It is the causative agent of sporotrichosis, which classically spreads via lymphatics, leading to a nodular lymphangitis.

 

Important OrganismsTransmittedin Linear/Sporotrichoid Pattern

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Staphylococcus aureus typically does not spread through the dermal and subcutaneous lymphatics as commonly as the other organisms listed, which are known for this pattern of dissemination.

 

Ref:  Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 105.51

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4thEdition Page No 9

questions.text: All of the following are types of skin tuberculosis EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lichen Planus

 

Option C:

 

  • Lichen planus is not a form of skin tuberculosis.
  • It is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by polygonal, flat-topped, violaceous papules and plaques with white reticulated lines (Wickham'sstriae).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lupus Vulgaris:

 

  • Lupus vulgaris is indeed a type of skin tuberculosis. It is a chronic, progressive form that typically presents with reddish-brown nodules and plaques that can ulcerate or scar.

 

Option B. Scrofuloderma:

 

  • Scrofuloderma is a type of skin tuberculosis that occurs due to direct extension from an underlying focus of infection, such as an infected lymph node or bone.

 

Option D. Lichen Scrofulosorum:

 

  • Lichen scrofulosorum is a tuberculid, a type of skin condition that represents a hypersensitivity reaction to tuberculosis or its antigens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lichen planus is not a type of skin tuberculosis but a separate chronic inflammatory skin disorder.
  • Lupus vulgaris, Scrofuloderma, and lichen scrofulosorum are all associated with tuberculosis.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 27.25

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4thEdition Page No 1307

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a large painless ulcer on the lower extremity as shown in the image below. The ulcer has a necrotic base and undermined edges. He has no systemic symptoms. His family reports that they live near a wetland area in a region known to have cases of similar ulcers. There has been no response to standard wound care and antibiotic treatment for common bacterial skin infections. A smear from the lesion shows acid-fast bacilli.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Buruli ulcer:

 

Option A:

 

  • Buruli ulcer is caused by Mycobacterium Ulcerans, which is endemic to wetland areas. It presents as a painless ulcer with necrosis and undermined edges.
  • Acid-fast bacilli in a smear from the lesion support the diagnosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Cutaneous Tuberculosis:

 

  • Although cutaneous tuberculosis is caused by an acid-fast bacillus (Mycobacterium tuberculosis), it typically presents in areas with a high prevalence of tuberculosis.

 

Option C. Cutaneous Leishmaniasis:

 

  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis causes skin ulcers, but these are typically painful and often associated with travel to endemic areas, such as the Middle East or South America.
  • A smear would show Leishmania parasites, not acid-fast bacilli.

 

Option D. Diabetic Ulcer:

 

  • Diabetic ulcers are typically found on pressure points of the feet, are associated with neuropathy and vascular disease, and do not usually present with undermined edges or a necrotic base unless secondarily infected.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presentation of a large, painless ulcer with a necrotic base and undermined edges in a patient from a wetland area, with a smear showing acid-fast bacilli, is characteristic of Buruli ulcer, caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans.
